response.answer_text: Are mathematicians normal people? The poor and mediocre ones are. :) The best mathematicians are sufficiently divergent from normal that they become the subject of mathematician jokes that are genuinely funny, like this one: The famous mathematician and computer scientist Professor John von Neumann said goodbye to his wife as he prepared to leave for his morning class. “Now remember, dear,” she told him, “the movers are coming today, so don’t walk back here when you leave Princeton this afternoon. Go to the new house.” Of course he forgot and walked back to their old house, only to find the locks had been changed, and looking through the window, the inside was empty. But luckily a child was sitting on the front stoop. He asked her, “Excuse me, little girl, but do you happen to know where the von Neumanns moved to?” She looked up at him, smiled, took his hand, and said, “Come on, Daddy. I’ll take you home.” Truly great mathematicians don’t understand why this is funny. But what’s even sadder is that you need to actually know math in order to appreciate the better mathematician jokes: Two math professors had a routine of meeting at the local bar after classes every Friday afternoon. Their conversation always seemed to turn to their undergraduate students, and this Friday was no different. Their discussion evolved into a friendly argument about whether it was worthwhile to teach Calculus to undergrads: would the course give them any lifelong skills and understanding, or would they simply forget everything they’d been taught as soon as the final bell rang at the end of the semester? Professor Airdose argued that, even if they didn’t remember the specifics, students would benefit from learning how to approach problems, and from understanding the basics of limits, slopes, sums of infinitesimals, and so on. His colleague, Professor Girdle, argued that most students tuned out during class, anyway, and learned only just enough to (usually) pass the tests. They kept at this for most of an hour, until Prof. Girdle excused himself to use the facilities. While he was gone, Prof. Airdose took the opportunity to call the bartender, an attractive coed, and ask her to help him trick his friend. “When the other professor comes back, I’d like to ask you a math question. All you need to do is say ‘⅓ x³’ as the answer. Do you think you can do that?” The young lady nodded and returned to her work, mumbling to herself, “One thir-dex cubed, one thir-dex cubed.” Prof. Airdose began to wonder if this might have been a bad idea after all. Nonetheless, they briefly continued arguing upon Prof. Girdle’s return, until Prof. Airdose offered to settle the debate once and for all. “Excuse me, miss,” he said, waving the bartender over, “would you happen to know the integral of x² dx?” Beaming with pride, she parroted, “One third x cubed!” and began to walk away. As Prof. Girdle sat flabbergasted and a smug Prof. Airdose grinned from ear to ear, the bartender paused, looked over her shoulder at the two professors, and added, “plus a constant, of course.” It turns out that you can actually use math jokes to judge whether or not you’re a decent mathematician: One of von Neumann’s grad students (I’m telling you: von Neumann was an incredible mathematician!) wanted to see if he could stump the old professor, so he asked him “the one about the bird and the cars.” It goes like this: Two cars are facing each other, a mile apart. At a given signal, one starts driving toward the other at 35 M.P.H and the other starts driving toward the first at 25 M.P.H. Coincidentally, at exactly that moment, a bird leaves the front bumper of the first car and flies to the other car at a constant 120 M.P.H. For reasons known only to the bird, it immediately and instantaneously reverses direction upon reaching the bumper of the second car, returning to the first. It continues its ever-shortening journey back and forth between the cars until, in a remarkable example of storytelling mercy, the cars come to a halt exactly one bird’s-width apart. How far has the bird flown? Unsurprisingly, the student had hardly finished explaining the problem before von Neumann answered correctly, “Two miles, of course.” “Very clever, Professor! I see you know the trick!” replied the rather disappointed student. “What trick?” asked von Neumann. “I summed the series.” That one went over well with my pre-calc students just after we’d discussed sums and sigma notation. But when I’ve told it to my coworkers, one typically laughs out loud, several others politely listen quietly because they’ve heard it three dozen times before, and the rest are still waiting for the punch line.

Most are normal people, but there are exceptions, for example Paul Erdős: “Paul Erdős was one of the most brilliant and prolific mathematicians of the twentieth century. He was also, as Paul Hoffman documents in his book The Man Who Loved Only Numbers, a true eccentric—a ‘mathematical monk’ who lived out of a pair of suitcases, dressed in tattered suits, and gave away almost all the money he earned, keeping just enough to sustain his meager lifestyle; a hopeless bachelor who was extremely (perhaps abnormally) devoted to his mother and never learned to cook or even boil his own water for tea; and a fanatic workaholic who routinely put in nineteen-hour days, sleeping only a few hours a night. Erdős owed his phenomenal stamina to amphetamines—he took ten to twenty milligrams of Benzedrine or Ritalin daily. Worried about his drug use, a friend once bet Erdős that he wouldn’t be able to give up amphetamines for a month. Erdős took the bet and succeeded in going cold turkey for thirty days. When he came to collect his money, he told his friend, ‘You’ve showed me I’m not an addict. But I didn’t get any work done. I’d get up in the morning and stare at a blank piece of paper. I’d have no ideas, just like an ordinary person. You’ve set mathematics back a month.’ After the bet, Erdős promptly resumed his amphetamine habit, which he supplemented with shots of strong espresso and caffeine tablets. ‘A mathematician,’ he liked to say, ‘is a machine for turning coffee into theorems.'”

What is normal? Do you mean are they human? Yes they breath, they eat(sometimes), and sleep if they can like most people. I do very well with numbers always have, but I will say the abnormal thing I do is math while I sleep. Through college I only missed one question, through all my studies, simply wasn't paying attention. Teach would always give me bonus problems on my exams, just to make it difficult for me. People actually would get mad at me if I answered questions in lecture.. I remember people use to ask if I had already taking the courses, or why I am taking courses if I already know how to do it, but I didn't know until I seen it done once, but that's usually all I need. The few times I actually ran into any trouble I figure it out in my sleep. I don't know how it works, or why. Some how if I concentrate on a mathematical problem, focus on it in my mind for a few min, like a relaxed meditation, before going to bed my brain with solve it before I wake up the next day, like I said idk how or why. it just works, . I am not a mathematician.. , I do love it though. The sleep math freaked me out at first, then I started useing it and.. wow its like my own super power in a way. For awhile people didn't believe me until My ex felt she needed to test it.. so using her calculus book she would give me a random problem to solve each night for a week.and every night they would get tougher and be longer, she had failed out of calc twice so she really wanted to get me jammed up. I got every single one correct, I had done calc long ago so not super hard or surprising, but still that is a lot of numbers to program in your brain overnight somehow arrange them in my head solve it and still have a fresh answer that next day

The funny truth is that Mathematicians really are normal people who have a different skill set than most. They are trained in logic and challenge themselves to think on really deep complicated logical subjects. Most of the time their days are spent putting together logic structures to convey overarching messages which we call “Proofs”. Ultimately though, they have varying personalities, hopes, dreams, and goals just like everyone else. At their core, they function just like everyone else. Some lose sight of this because their way of thinking is valuable to many and they are put on a pedestal, but at the end of the day there isn’t anything different about who they are or how they function than anyone else. If you want to see people whoa re often a lot like Mathematicians, you can talk to professional musicians. I have a lot of friends who are in orchestras and symphonies at a high level, and their lives are extremely relatable to that of a Mathematician. There is a lot of grind work in the background to create and present something valuable to the rest of the world, and often very few people will ever appreciate what is presented.

We mathematicians have this joke: A room contains a stove; one burner is red-hot already. A kettle full of cold water is on the floor. The engineer and the mathematician were both asked “How would you make the water boil?” and both said “Put the kettle on the red-hot burner.” Now there’s a table in the room also, and the kettle full of cold water is on the table. “How would you make the water boil?” The engineer said “Place the kettle on the red-hot burner.” The mathematician said “Place the kettle on the floor; the problem is now reduced to a previously solved problem.”

A mathematician on the street, or in the grocery store, is pretty much indistinguishable from the common (wo)man. But if you live with a mathematician for several years you may begin to notice certain odd things, or so my girlfriend tells me. A mathematician may have an “odd” sense of humor. (S)he may be intrigued by seemingly innocuous phenomena (like what day of the year does the sunlight happen to shine through a window at the top of the stairs and graze each step then hit the toilet dead on?) A number theorist often knows factorizations of many large integers that others could care less about. And so on.

To be honest I think not if by people you mean human beings. I was not bad at maths at school but there was a potential genius amongst us. One rainy break he took the chalk and started an equation which was to prove that 1=0. He had pretty much finished and some of us were impressed (others were more normal and reading comics. Then the maths master strode in. “Boy!” he demanded as his gown and the embedded chalk dust settled. “What have you been… aha T******r. I see. Attempting to prove 1=0 and as a result fooling some of these perfectly sensible boys into believing you. Should you be able to show the cheat and explain how it is done you may merely clean the board. If not, it is a detention and clean the board”. T******r (he lives and is a professor somewhere) gleefully obliged and the master later admitted to being mildly impressed.

No. But neither is anyone else. In fact, I have a mathematical proof that no one is normal. I wrote it up somewhere, but can’t find it. Basically, the volume of a p-dimensional unit hypersphere (representing normal people) increases much slower than the volume of a p-dimensional unit hypercube (representing all people) as p increases.

People seem to get weird ideas of what professionals in various fields are like. Don’t assume anything weird about a group unless you have good reason. Once I went to a big AMS/MAA joint conference. The way to tell the difference between the mathematicians and the tourists was that the mathematicians were dressed a little like business people, because we were going to a conference. We all looked so average. Being a mathematician is a middle-class occupation, which seems to be becoming an unusual thing. Academic freedom and tenure used to make it a better job. Lack of intellectual curiosity is treated as normal but it’s not.

Not that I’m a mathematician but i think normality seem to be acceptance, and challenging that is in of itself an anti-social act, and thus abnormal we’re not up a tree somewhere scratching each other’s bottoms because we all refused to believe what we were told human progress is really a reasonably steady line in terms of technological progress modulo population actually the last 20 years haven’t been that great really - making a wheel rounder is much less use than making a lousy wheel when there was none that progress is largely an artefact of a strong urges to be societal and conformist i know this is more heresy but i think mathematicians largely these days are way TOO normal

No! They aren’t. They come up with logics and stepwise approach to every problem, unlike normal people. They will solve imaginary problems whereas, on another hand, normal people create imaginary problems. They think about all possibilities of an event, try to expand their thoughts to another dimension and even look at the statistics, to be rational human, whereas other normal people just don’t use common sense. even Nobel prize is given to just normal people. thus not to mathematicians. Probably the definition of normalcy is just a living human who can’t use the brain. In short, Here is a quote that I believe normal people can understand. “I have hardly ever known a mathematician who was capable of reasoning.”- Plato

No. No “normal” person becomes a mathematician. Being a mathematician is not something that just happens. You need an disproportionately higher ability for abstract reasoning than the general population to study mathematics and become a mathematician. The very fact that you are a mathematician means that you are not normal by any sense of the word. Average people don’t become mathematicians. Even if we assume there are 1 millions mathematicians on earth today (a gross overestimation, btw), that’s still about 0.014% of the population! Mathematicians are an elite group of thinkers, so they are definitely not normal people! :P

I would say so. There are a lot of jokes about how strange mathematicians are, but in general they are normal. There is a famous joke about people driving on a train and looking out the window and seeing a flock of sheep which are black. The first person who is a normal person says i see sheep, the second says i see black sheep, so I think that that all sheep are black in this country (he is apparently a practical physicist), the third one who is a mathematician says, there exist sheep in this country and they are black from at least one side.

I'm not sure how to answer this. The fellow mathematicians I've met are an eclectic bunch, they fall in love, or not, they're faithful to their wives, or not, they have children, or not, they get drunk, or not, they have a favourite football team, or not. They ask stupid questions, or am I thinking about some other category of humans there?

If you are a mathematician, I think you would say that you are. It is when the mathematicians put forward ridiculous ideas, that you a start to wonder. Especially when they say, that the maths tells them something. This happens when they put forward the idea, that it is irrelevant whether time goes forward or backwards, as the maths allows it to happen. This is one of those reasons when I think, that they must have been born on a different planet. But we are all special in our own way.

Mathematicians are normal people… . . . … except when they're oblique! *ducking* Mathematicians are not obtuse, but I have been called a cute mathematician…. Many mathematicians are set in their paths, while others have a random disposition.  Correlation

I can’t speak for all mathematicians. I *pretend* I am “normal” and yet there is still something in my wiring that is definitely “Abby somebody.” Yes, “Abby normal”. 😉. Everyone is odd in some fashion. Many math people are odd as well. Is that “normal”? That is subjective and hard to measure. But personally I like the math and no math people who embrace this idea that we are all odd in some way. It allows one to chuckle about it and carry on. Note: “Abby normal” is from the film “Young Frankenstein”. Modestly known quote.

I have always thought mathematicians are just normal people. I've known a few and had no idea what they did until they told me. They act just like anybody else. They have hobbies just like anybody else. You can't tell them apart from regular people. Then I stumbled across a photo that forever changed my mind. Take a look at this and judge for yourself.

Didn’t you know that we mathematicians do other things too? This one dances, collects crystals & cacti, climbs mountains, drinks, eats and does other things (like most of you) not mentionable on Quora. This mathematician even wastes his time replying to silly questions when he could be dealing with serious mathematical problems on this site!
Professional mathematics are typically on the NORMAL curve, but at least one standard deviation above the mean. ;-)

Pretty much the same as any othe stem person; I am an engineer and ahve a few pure math friends, there is not a difference between the math guys and the other stem guys. The funniest part, the stem guys themselves are not that different from normal people; as I type this I work for kenworth trucking, when someone askes me where I work I answer kenworth and they think I am a truck driver.
There are seven to eight times more Asperger's spectrum disordered among mathematicians than in any other profession. This is taken from a book by Masha Gessen about Russian mathematician Perelman.
Of course. They just happen to be good at mathematics. By the same token athletes are normal people who happen to be good at sports. And so on….
No, not at all. At night we feast upon raw human brains. Psst don't tell anyone. Watch out, your brain may be next!
